intro: Carumbium pedicellatum, commonly known as the clustered bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its clusters of bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in cooler, moist environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and branched. Carumbium pedicellatum is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and botanical collections.
